title: Justice Barrett Joins the Court
summary: A landmark for the judiciary, without any guaranteed outcomes.. Justice Amy Coney Barrett, as she will now be known, was confirmed by the Senate 52-48 on Monday evening, with a swearing-in shortly thereafter. A few congratulations are in order, as well as some thoughts about the future of the Supreme Court.

title: NIH Halts Study Exploring Treating Covid-19 With Lilly Antibody, Remdesivir
summary: The study, paused due to a safety concern, won't resume because the combination drug treatment didn't show any signs of benefit. Federal health researchers have halted testing a combination of Eli Lilly & Co.'s Covid-19 antibody drug and remdesivir in hospitalized Covid-19 patients, after an independent committee found a lack of a benefit.

title: Election Officials Warn of Widespread Suspicious Email Campaign
summary: Security officials worry that local election representatives might be susceptible to online trickery. Local U.S. election officials have been receiving suspicious emails that appear to be part of a widespread and potentially malicious campaign targeting several states, according to a private alert about the activity.

title: Supreme Court Rejects Pandemic-Spurred Voting Changes in Wisconsin
summary: Mail-In ballots must arrive by Election Day in critical state, dealing Democrats a loss. WASHINGTON-The Supreme Court on Monday declined to allow pandemic-related changes to voting rules in Wisconsin, a move that means mail-in ballots must be received by Election Day in a leading battleground state.

title: Sheldon Adelson's Las Vegas Sands Considers Sale of Casinos in Namesake City
summary: Operations on the Strip potentially priced at more than $6 billion. Casino mogul Sheldon Adelson's Las Vegas Sands Corp. is considering a sale of its Las Vegas Strip operations, including two resorts and a huge convention hall, a company spokesman said.

title: New York City Students Get One More Shot to Take In-Person Classes
summary: Failing grades to be replaced with 'needs improvement' or 'course in progress'. New York City public school students currently enrolled in fully remote instruction will have only one opportunity this academic year to switch to a hybrid blend of virtual learning and in-person instruction, officials said Monday.

title: Study Shows Covid-19 Antibodies Waning Over Time, Suggesting Immunity Might Wear Off
summary: If confirmed, results suggest widespread long-term herd immunity will be difficult to achieve. LONDON-A large English study showed the number of people with Covid-19 antibodies declined significantly over the summer, suggesting that getting the virus might not confer long-lasting immunity from future infection.

title: New York's Mayor Says Early Voting Sites Need More Staff, Machines
summary: Mayor Bill de Blasio says city would provide any funding that the Board of Elections needs to improve operations. More than 300,000 people in New York City cast ballots for the presidential election during the first three days of early voting, officials said, but hourslong waits sparked calls for more voting sites and other reforms.

title: Blackstone Raises $8 Billion for Second Long-Life Fund
summary: Blackstone collected the pool during the early days of the coronavirus pandemic, which slowed fundraising across the industry. Blackstone Group Inc. has collected $8.2 billion for its long-hold private-equity fund, raising most of it during the initial surge of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: How Nicole Kidman Convinced Hugh Grant to Star With Her in 'The Undoing'
summary: Watch the Academy Award-winning actor's intimate chat for our new live conversation series, The One, with WSJ. Magazine's Editor-in-Chief Kristina O'Neill.. On Monday night, Oscar-winning actor Nicole Kidman joined WSJ. Magazine editor-in-chief Kristina O'Neill for an intimate chat as part of the magazine's new conversation series, The One. Tiffany & Co. was a presenting sponsor for the event.

title: Man Kills Woman, Then Himself on Busy Manhattan Street
summary: The incident follows a week of violent crime in New York City. A man fatally shot and stabbed a woman before killing himself on a busy street in Manhattan's Financial District on Monday, New York Police Department officials said.

title: Doug Jones Faces Long Odds in Keeping Alabama Senate Seat
summary: Democrat squares off against Republican former football coach Tommy Tuberville in deeply red state. Alabama's Sen. Doug Jones, the most vulnerable Democrat up for re-election, has staked out centrist positions while also taking high-profile votes against President Trump during his three years in office and now faces an uphill battle to defend his seat in the deeply red state.

title: U.S. Sanctions Iran's Petroleum Ministry, National Iranian Oil Company, Tanker Subsidiary
summary: Pre-election move makes it more difficult for pressure campaign to be reversed, analysts say. The Trump administration on Monday imposed counterterrorism sanctions on Iran's Ministry of Petroleum, the National Iranian Oil Company and its tanker subsidiary in a pre-election move that analysts say will make it more difficult for the pressure campaign to be reversed in the future.

title: How 50 Cent Becomes 20 Cent
summary: The rapper discovers the reality of Joe Biden's tax plan.. Sometimes you have to wonder if there's anything rappers could utter that would offend modern progressive sensibilities. Apparently, there is. Rapper Curtis James Jackson III, who goes by the stage name 50 Cent, last week outraged the left by endorsing President Trump in opposition to Joe Biden's confiscatory tax plan.

title: Nevada Does a California
summary: A steep renewable energy mandate is on the ballot that would mean higher electricity costs and shortages.. California's blackouts this summer presented a cautionary lesson about purging fossil fuels from the power supply. Nevadans can heed the warning and reject a referendum to enshrine a 50% renewable electricity mandate in the state constitution.

title: Behold the Mighty Ant
summary: What are investors buying in the world's largest initial public offering?. Everything about China's economy is stupendously big, and so it is that financial-services company Ant Group will become the world's largest initial public offering when it hits the Hong Kong and Shanghai stock exchanges next month. But what are investors buying?

title: Thoma Bravo Raises $22.8 Billion in Record Tech-Fundraising Haul
summary: The firm's flagship fund collected $17.8 billion, a milestone for a tech-focused buyout fund. Thoma Bravo, a private-equity firm focused on technology and software, has collected $22.8 billion from investors for three funds in one of the largest tech-focused private-equity fundraising hauls to date.

title: Hospital Merger Seeks to Create Regional Giant in the West
summary: Intermountain Healthcare, Sanford Health would operate 69 hospitals across six states; Intermountain CEO says to expect more deal making. Utah's largest hospital system, Intermountain Healthcare, will expand into the Midwest with a proposed merger to create a regional hospital giant, the latest pairing amid a spate of consolidation in the sector.

title: We May Get a Conservative Chief Justice
summary: If Roberts joins the liberals, Thomas gets to assign the opinion.. 'Chief Justice Thomas" was the headline of an article I wrote in the Journal late in 2004. I urged President George W. Bush to elevate Justice Clarence Thomas if Chief Justice William Rehnquist retired the following year. Mr. Bush didn't follow my advice when Rehnquist died in September 2005. But as Amy Coney Barrett dons her high-court robe, Justice Thomas may find himself filling an unaccustomed leadership role.

title: Trump's Google Lawsuit Could Prove a Poison Pill for Biden
summary: The Justice Department's action would force a new administration to quit equivocating on antitrust.. It is unusual for the Justice Department to announce a major antitrust suit shortly before a presidential election, especially when the incumbent is expected to lose. It is even more unusual when the administration bringing the suit is admittedly pro-business. It's all so unusual that it is tempting to see the government's recent suit against Google as a gigantic poison pill the Trump administration is leaving for Joe Biden.

title: China to Sanction U.S. Arms Makers Over Sales to Taiwan
summary: Washington last week approved deals totaling $1.8 billion for Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Raytheon. HONG KONG-China said it will sanction three American defense contractors over proposed arms sales to Taiwan, retaliating against U.S. efforts to deepen security ties with the island democracy that Beijing claims as its territory.

title: Notable & Quotable: A Footnote to a Biden Endorsement
summary: 'While Joe Biden is the clear choice for president, it would be a disservice to the country to send him to the White House without a backstop.'. From "Our choice is Joe Biden*," an editorial in the New Hampshire Union Leader, Oct. 25:

title: What in the World if Trump Wins?
summary: In a second term, expect more chaotic, confident wheeling and dealing overseas.. The odds are against him again, but Donald Trump has every intention of winning four more years in office. In foreign policy at least, his second term would likely be even more transformative and unconventional than his first.

title: 'The Last Sovereigns' Review: Across the Medicine Line
summary: After Little Big Horn, the Lakota chief Sitting Bull led his followers to Canada. An international standoff loomed.. Robert M. Utley has been called "the Dean of Western History," a fitting moniker given the nearly two dozen books he has published on subjects ranging from Billy the Kid to the Texas Rangers, not to mention his tenure as chief historian of the National Park Service. Perhaps Mr. Utley's finest achievement is "The Lance and the Shield," his celebrated 1993 biography of Sitting Bull, the Hunkpapa Lakota chief and holy man forever linked by the Battle of the Little Bighorn to Gen. George Armstrong Custer, whose dashing military exploits have captivated Mr. Utley since boyhood. But as he explains in the preface to his new book, Mr. Utley has long felt that, like other biographers of Sitting Bull, he hadn't paid sufficient attention to the chief's "Canadian Years," the four-year period when Sitting Bull and his followers sought refuge north of the border in the aftermath of Custer's annihilation. Now, at the age of 90, Mr. Utley has attempted to fill that gap with "The Last Sovereigns: Sitting Bull and the Resistance of the Free Lakotas."

title: Saving Private Biden
summary: The press standard for 2020: No tough questions for the former vice president.. In the thick of the 2016 presidential campaign, the front page of the New York Times handed down the word from on high: In the era of Donald Trump, press objectivity was a luxury America could not afford.

title: China Is Far Behind on U.S. Purchases Under Trade Deal
summary: Farm sales have shown improvement, but like other categories are well below 2020 target. WASHINGTON-China accelerated purchases of U.S. farm products last month, new data shows, but overall it remains far behind on a commitment to buy about $140 billion in specific U.S. agricultural, energy and manufactured goods this year under a trade accord signed in January.

title: Trump and Biden Take Different Tacks in Campaign's Final Week
summary: As the president crisscrosses the country for rallies, the Democratic nominee relies on ads and virtual events amid coronavirus pandemic. President Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden are employing divergent tactics in the final week before Election Day, with Mr. Trump set to crisscross the country for campaign rallies while Mr. Biden's operation floods the airwaves and relies on a more virtual approach.

title: Global Insurer AIG to Divest Life-Insurance Business
summary: Current President Peter Zaffino will run the insurer as CEO starting March 1. Insurance conglomerate American International Group Inc. is taking steps to split off its life-insurance business into a separate company, leaving it to focus on property-casualty insurance, a separation it will make under the direction of a new chief executive.

title: Investors Pare Bets on Postelection Currency Volatility
summary: Asset managers are unwinding positions in foreign exchange that paid out if markets went haywire around the vote. Investors are reducing bets on extreme volatility in currency markets around the U.S. presidential election.

title: More Water on the Moon? New Finding Deepens Puzzle
summary: Detection of water in a sunny lunar crater raises new questions on how water exists on the moon. Astronomers from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration for the first time have detected water molecules on the sunlit surface of the moon, raising hopes that water there may be more plentiful than previously believed, the space agency said Monday.

title: Need a Pandemic Puppy ASAP? Call the Bernedoodle Delivery People
summary: Resume Subscription. During a business-trip layover, Sue Murphy fired off a quick update to her client, software entrepreneur Max Faingezicht, who had waited seven long months to conclude this deal.

title: Dow Falls 650 Points on Virus Uptick, Fading Stimulus Hopes
summary: The U.S. and several countries in Europe face elevated case levels, fueling concern over additional restrictions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 650 points Monday as coronavirus cases surged, adding to worries about the economic outlook after Congress and the White House failed to agree on a much-anticipated fiscal stimulus deal.

title: Protesters Sue New York City Mayor, Police Officials Over Handling of Protests
summary: The protests earlier this year were sparked by the May 25 killing of George Floyd. Eleven protesters on Monday filed a lawsuit against New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio and New York Police Department officials, accusing them of playing a role in the alleged misconduct of some officers during Black Lives Matter demonstrations in the city over the summer.

title: A Key to Healthier Adult Diets: Healthier Baby Diets
summary: As the federal government weighs the first-ever dietary guidelines for children under 2, there's evidence that the food habits of young kids influence their diet-and their health-later on. Feeding babies the right healthy foods during a critical window of time may help set them up for better health as adults, emerging research suggests.

title: SAP Casts a Cloud Over Software
summary: Pandemic's duration weighs on software giant's outlook and could affect even the hottest cloud names. A crush of workers sent home earlier this year turned out to be good for a lot of tech companies. Keeping them home might not be.

title: Newark Imposes Covid-19 Restrictions on Businesses
summary: New Jersey health officials blame pandemic fatigue, indoor gatherings for increase in coronavirus cases. Newark officials ordered all nonessential businesses to close nightly by 8 p.m. and strongly urged residents not to trick-or-treat or hold Halloween celebrations, as Covid-19 cases surged in New Jersey's largest city.

title: Russian Airstrikes Kill Dozens of Turkey-Backed Fighters in Syria, Rebels Say
summary: Targeted group describes attack on training camp as Moscow and Ankara face off in several conflicts. BEIRUT-Russian airstrikes killed dozens of Turkey-backed fighters in northwestern Syria on Monday, according to a spokesman for the fighters and a commander in the targeted group, in a deadly escalation of violence that puts a fragile cease-fire at risk.

title: Spooked (Tuesday Crossword, October 27)
'Magic Oneohtrix Point Never' Review: An Ode to Radio With No Dead Air
summary: Daniel Lopatin, aka Oneohtrix Point Never, offers a maximalist album that honors a bygone listening experience.

title: Singing at a Social Distance
summary: Opera companies' online offerings, including White Snake Projects' ambitious 'Alice in the Pandemic,' continue to explore the possibilities of virtual performance..

title: That Big Trump Jobs Boom Was No Illusion
summary: Prof. Blinder fails to inform us that the pre-pandemic boom reversed 15 years of declining labor-force participation, drove jobless rates to a 50-year low and advanced black employment to record levels. Regarding Alan Blinder's "The Trump 'Jobs Boom' Is a Convenient Myth" (op-ed, Oct. 22): Prof. Blinder fails to inform us that the pre-pandemic boom reversed 15 years of declining labor-force participation, drove jobless rates to a 50-year low and advanced black employment to record levels. At the same time, our economy finally broke out from 16 years of a flatlined median-household income, and saw household net worth climb to over $100 trillion, a record level. Best of all, lower-income Americans finally began to participate in our prosperity. Call this dumb luck or a myth-just give us more of it.

title: Let the Private Sector Compete to Charge EVs
summary: The spread of utility-owned chargers is one of the biggest impediments to that private-sector investment.. "Utilities Wage Battle Over Charging Stations" (Business & Finance, Oct. 19) raises important questions about whether U.S. consumers in the future will get the benefit of price competition and innovation spurred by the private market. Many advocates of electric vehicles mistakenly assume that the quickest and most effective way to increase charging options for consumers is to have electric utilities build, own and operate those chargers.

title: Biden's Plan Will Strengthen Social Security
summary: In times like these people are relying on Social Security now more than ever. It has never missed a payment and Joe Biden's plan will ensure it remains that way without cutting benefits.. Andrew Biggs's "The Hidden Trap in Biden's Tax Hike" (op-ed, Oct. 19) criticizes Joe Biden's plan for Social Security, but is wrong on many counts.

title: Don't Write Off Teachers' Reasonable Fears of Covid
summary: There is still a Covid pandemic and it's getting worse, not better. The vast majority of teachers aren't going to risk their lives, no matter how much they wish they could teach directly.. Regarding David R. Henderson and Ryan Sullivan's "End the School Shutdown" (op-ed, Oct. 21): My devoted teacher-wife and all of her colleagues would love to get back in the classroom with their students. But they have to draw the line at risking their lives to do it. They are inundated daily with media and government leaders proclaiming the danger of being surrounded by tons of people in tight, unventilated spaces. Governors across the nation are shutting down businesses, claiming this is the best way to protect people, but being crammed into schools would be safe?

title: Oil Drops on Covid-19 Resurgence, Extra Libyan Crude
summary: Curbs on travel and leisure in Europe threaten to dent demand as quickening Libyan output boosts supplies. Oil prices fell Monday after new coronavirus restrictions in Europe and the speedy return of production in Libya threatened to undermine efforts to chip away at a global glut of crude.

title: The Senate's Oil Transitioners
summary: Even before the election, Democrats try to cut off energy financing.. Joe Biden's admission at last week's debate that he wants to transition America away from oil puts him in the company of a number of congressional Democrats who have been pressuring banks not to finance lawful energy ventures.

title: BuzzFeed Expects to Break Even, Thanks to Heavy Cost Cuts
summary: Digital media company's revenue damaged during pandemic as layoffs, other cuts shore up bottom line. At the end of a staff-wide video call in early October about improving diversity, BuzzFeed Chief Executive Jonah Peretti revealed some good news: The company is on target to break even this year for the first time since 2014.

title: How Do States Verify Signatures on Mail-In Ballots?
summary: Most states use automated signature-verification applications, but there isn't a uniform system. A: Many states will compare the signature on the absentee ballot envelope to the signature on a voter's file (this could be from voter registration forms, ballot application or the D.M.V.), according to data collected by the National Conference of State Legislatures. Processing a mail ballot is time-consuming and can involve a mix of automation and manual steps. Envelopes need to be opened and ballots flattened to prepare them to be scanned for counting. One type of technology that may be used is automated signature-verification applications, in which a camera captures the voter's signature from the ballot return envelope as it is being sorted. The image is then compared with the reference image from the voter registration database.

title: Voting by Mail? How to Track Your Election Ballot
summary: Most states offer ways to follow your ballot during the 2020 election. A: Nearly all states offer voters the ability to check the status of their mail-in ballots, somewhat like tracking delivery for an item ordered online. The type of tracking available to you depends on what state you live in and sometimes, as in Texas and Illinois, which county.

title: How Covid-Safe Is Dining in a Restaurant's Outdoor Tent?
summary: As restaurants build structures for outdoor meals in cool weather, what are the risks of virus transmission?. As restaurants gear up to extend outdoor dining in colder parts of the country, many are seating guests in enclosed and sometimes heated structures. But when it comes to virus transmission, is eating in covered outdoor setups less risky than inside?

title: Thailand's King Becomes Foreign Relations Challenge for Germany
summary: Protesters in Bangkok ask Berlin to investigate their monarch's stays in Bavaria. Pro-democracy protesters in Thailand who are taking on their country's powerful and secretive monarchy are turning to Germany for answers.

title: Dunkin' Brands in Talks to Be Acquired by Arby's Parent
summary: The owner of Dunkin' and Baskin-Robbins held early talks to go private in an acquisition by Inspire Brands, which holds chains including Arby's. The parent of Dunkin' and Baskin-Robbins said it has held early talks to go private in an acquisition by Inspire Brands Inc., whose portfolio includes the Arby's, Buffalo Wild Wings and Jimmy John's restaurant chains.

title: SAP Profit Warning Sends Shares Plummeting
summary: Europe's biggest tech company posts biggest intraday drop in 21 years. BERLIN- SAP SE shares plunged more than 20% Monday after Europe's biggest technology company by sales scrapped its profit targets for the year and said measures to thwart a rebound in coronavirus infections would weigh on business through the middle of next year.

title: Campaigns Rush to Submit Facebook Ads Ahead of Limits
summary: Ban on new political ads in final week before Election Day has groups looking to new platforms, social-media influencers. Republican and Democratic political advertisers are scrambling to submit their ads to Facebook Inc. before the end of Monday after the social network decided not to allow new political ads in the week leading up to Election Day.

title: Baseball Cut Corey Seager's Video Feed. Dodgers Star Is Even Better.
summary: The All-Star shortstop prefers the instant feedback from video reviews during games, but new protocols prevent him from doing so in 2020. ARLINGTON, Texas-In a typical season, Corey Seager doesn't spend much time in the Los Angeles Dodgers dugout when his team is hitting. He estimates that about two-thirds of the time he is hunched over a computer monitor in the team's replay room, dissecting his previous swings to make quick adjustments before his next at-bat.

title: The American Experiment Is on Life Support
summary: Neo-Marxists on the street and in institutions want to erase their opponents and deconstruct the country.. 'Death to America!" is a common refrain from antifa rioters from Portland, Ore., to Kenosha, Wis. Children are in the streets calling for the country's destruction while mobs of college kids trash public spaces, filming themselves as though part of a performance-art spectacle. Neither political party has been willing or able to end this anarchy. Extremism becomes more entrenched in American politics with each passing day.

title: Media Watchdogs Aren't Supposed to Guard Biden
summary: If the Democrats win, will America's free press become an instrument of state propaganda?. All Things, it seems, will not be Considered. In the long and dishonorable annals of journalistic cant, there have been few statements to compete with the one issued by National Public Radio last week explaining why it wouldn't burden its listeners with any news about Hunter Biden.

title: Why Porsche and BMW Are Gunning for Hoodie-Wearing Teens
summary: Luxury auto makers are trying to lure in younger fans through hyped-up partnerships with insidery clothing companies like Aimé Leon Dore, Kith and Supreme. EARLY THIS FEBRUARY, before we all began sheltering in place, visitors streamed into the Jeffrey Deitch Gallery in downtown Manhattan to ogle a one-of-a-kind Porsche .

title: How Delayed Is Your Mail-In Ballot?
summary: Resume Subscription. The U.S. Postal Service has urged voters to mail in their presidential ballots at least a week before their state's due date to be counted.

title: JPMorgan Currency Deal Highlights Finance's Green Shift
summary: U.S. bank and Italian utility company Enel enter into a green cross-currency basis swap. Green finance is making tracks into the wonky world of foreign-exchange markets, highlighting the lengths Wall Street will go to broadcast an environmental angle on investments.

title: Dunkin' Buyout Talks Will Fuel Deal Hunger
summary: Even at a rich valuation and a continuing pandemic, private equity will find much to love in businesses like Dunkin' Brands. Shareholders across the restaurant industry got some welcome news: Private equity wants to eat.

title: Can Gap Escape the Whirlwind? New CEO Confronts Years of Decline
summary: Sonia Syngal is plotting a future of fewer stores and more fashion risks to revive the company's namesake brand. In late March, Gap Inc., the perennially struggling retailer, temporarily closed all its North American stores in response to the Covid-19 lockdown and lost 70% of its revenue overnight.

title: United Nations (Saturday Crossword, October 24)
Robert Murray, Stubborn U.S. Coal Titan, Dies at Age 80
summary: Entrepreneur's Murray Energy, built through aggressive acquisitions, filed for bankruptcy a year ago. Robert E. Murray, who used an aggressive acquisition strategy to build Murray Energy Corp. into a coal-mining giant even as falling prices drove rivals out of business, died Sunday at his home in St. Clairsville, Ohio, his lawyer, Michael Shaheen, said.

title: ETF Clones Multiply in Industry Fee War
summary: Invesco and other ETF industry executives say they need copycat funds to attract cost-conscious individual investors. The race to zero on Wall Street is so competitive that some of the biggest asset managers are creating cheaper knockoffs of their most popular exchange-traded funds.

title: Break Up Big Tech Earnings
summary: There is no reason why Apple, Amazon.com, Facebook, Twitter and Alphabet should all report the same day. Is there excessive concentration among America's biggest technology companies? In at least one respect, the answer is undoubtedly yes.

title: A Trump Election Comeback? With These Pieces, It's Still Possible
summary: The president would need to stitch together support from a few key demographic groups and the right combination of states. For those in the business of writing about politics, the question you are asked most frequently these days is: Could President Trump still win?

title: Ant to Raise More Than $34 Billion in Record IPO
summary: The mammoth initial public offering adds to an already frenetic year for China's capital markets. HONG KONG-Chinese financial-technology giant Ant Group Co. is set to raise at least $34.4 billion from the world's biggest-ever initial public offering, filings showed Monday, in a blockbuster deal that will bypass U.S. stock exchanges.

title: A Season of Lost Games and Lost Quarterbacks for the Dallas Cowboys
summary: Dak Prescott and Andy Dalton both went down, leaving the 2-5 Cowboys to turn to rookie quarterback Ben DiNucci inside the bumbling NFC East. The Dallas Cowboys had big plans for the 2020 season. None of them involved a guy named Ben DiNucci.

title: Police Struggle to Protect Voters and Avoid Intimidation at Polls
summary: Concern about police presence at voting sites dates to Jim Crow era, when police intimidated Black voters. States and cities across the U.S. are wrestling with a delicate task as they gear up for the possibility of violence on Election Day: how to keep voters safe without deploying a police presence that could intimidate some voters.

title: Facebook Moves Into Cloud Gaming
summary: Social-media company's free-to-play model differs from paid, subscription cloud-gaming services of rivals such as Google and Microsoft.

title: Hospitals Balance Covid-19 Care With More-Lucrative Services During Latest Virus Surge
summary: More experience with the coronavirus means hospitals are keeping other services open as the pandemic intensifies. Hospitals are holding off as long as possible before halting procedures to make room for fresh waves of Covid-19 patients, a reversal from earlier this year when facilities postponed care, leading to steep financial losses and public-health risks.

title: Nigeria Protests: What's Happening and Why Are People Demonstrating Against SARS?
summary: Protests against a notorious police unit have mushroomed into a broader movement, posing a challenge to the government of Africa's most populous nation. Two weeks of nationwide protests against police brutality in Nigeria turned deadly on Oct. 20 as security forces fired live rounds on demonstrators, killing several people. The decision to use military force to quell the demonstrations shifts politics into an uncertain phase in West Africa's most populous nation and largest oil producer.

title: Chile Votes to Change Pinochet-Era Constitution
summary: Referendum sets in motion a two-year process to draft a new charter in Chile. Chileans voted overwhelmingly to change their dictatorship-era constitution in a referendum on Sunday, beginning a process that could upend the political landscape in one of Latin America's wealthiest nations amid a social backlash against the status quo.

title: Return of Big Las Vegas Shows Proves to Be a High-Wire Act
summary: 'Absinthe' to reopen in test of whether freewheeling entertainment can conform to Covid-19 rules and still turn a profit. LAS VEGAS-The cabaret-variety show "Absinthe" became a long-running hit by putting performers uncomfortably close to audiences in a circus tent outside Caesars Palace.

title: Dunkin' Brands, Hasbro, Apple: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Resume Subscription. S&P 500 futures are falling as coronavirus cases surge in the U.S. and Europe and stimulus hopes fade.

title: Why the Time Change Is Trickier When Working From Home
summary: A missing commute and changes in light may intensify effects, scientists say; here's advice on how to 'fall back' in the pandemic. After clocks turn back an hour Nov. 1, David K. Welsh, who works from home, plans a few changes. "I will make more of an effort to see daylight in the morning," says Dr. Welsh, who studies the body's internal clock as a professor in the Department of Psychiatry & Center for Circadian Biology at the University of California, San Diego. His reasoning? Going outside to take advantage of the extra hour of sunlight earlier in the morning can boost alertness and help synchronize circadian rhythms.

title: Firms Use Business-School Recruiting Tools to Diversify
summary: Companies use virtual tools to reach out to schools with more Black students as they aim to fulfill diversity commitments. Companies are recruiting more business students at historically Black colleges and universities this year in an attempt to diversify their talent pipelines.

title: Makeup Mogul Bobbi Brown Launches New Beauty Venture Jones Road
summary: Ever since cosmetics pioneer Bobbi Brown left her namesake brand in 2016, she has been waiting for her moment to get back into the game. The time has finally come.. "I don't remember when I wasn't aware of who Bobbi Brown was," says Mickey Drexler, former CEO of J.Crew and the Gap and a current strategic partner at clothing brand Alex Mill. "I didn't even know her and I knew who she was because her name lends itself to who she is: it's not a fancy cosmetic company name, it's Bobbi Brown." That sense of relatability is at the core of the makeup mogul's personal appeal and her business credo. Even so, Brown herself hasn't been the person behind the Bobbi Brown Cosmetics brand since 2016, when she left Estée Lauder . She had worked there for over two decades after selling the company her brand in 1995 in a reported $74.5 million deal. After waiting out a four-year non-compete agreement, she's starting a new beauty venture.

title: Bobbi Brown's Jones Road
summary: Ever since cosmetics pioneer Bobbi Brown left her namesake brand in 2016, she has been waiting for her moment to get back into the game. The time has come.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Hollywood Tattoo Artist Dr. Woo on the Most Intricate Tattoo He's Inked During the Pandemic
summary: "I [usually] do almost 10 [tattoos] a week and now I'm down to three," says Woo, who's known for the designs he's done for Drake, Zoë Kravitz, Miley Cyrus and more. In our series My Monday Morning, self-motivated people tell WSJ. how they start off the week.

title: Kershaw Is Conquering a World Series. Yes, You Read That Correctly.
summary: A second straight victory for a playoff-tormented ace puts Los Angeles on the brink of their first World Series title since 1988. Clayton Kershaw doesn't have much to prove. At 32, he's assembled one of the great pitching résumés in Major League history, a 13-season run which, according to the statistics compendium Baseball-Reference.com, tracks closely with the numbers of Pedro Martinez, Roger Clemens and Lefty Grove. Kershaw's all-time regular-season record is 175 wins against 76 losses, and he possesses a comically-low lifetime earned-run average of 2.43. He has won the National League's Cy Young Award three times, and the NL's Most Valuable Player once. He is well paid for this: Kershaw has earned more than $225 million over the course of his career, all of which has taken place with one of the signature franchises in the sport, the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Auto Makers Shift Hydrogen Focus to Big Rigs
summary: GM, Toyota, Hyundai pivot fuel-cell efforts after years of developing the technology for smaller vehicles, with little success. Auto makers have spent decades developing hydrogen fuel cells as a green alternative for cars with little to show for it. Now, they are shifting their attention to the trucking industry.

title: Republican Congressman Fights for Re-Election After Party Switch
summary: New Jersey Rep. Jeff Van Drew is in a tight race against Democratic challenger Amy Kennedy.

title: Oxford, AstraZeneca Vaccine Shows Promising Immune Response in Older Adults
summary: AstraZeneca says an interim analysis of the vaccine candidate, now in late-stage human trials, was encouraging. LONDON-A Covid-19 vaccine being developed by the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca PLC showed a promising immune response and low levels of adverse reactions in the elderly and older adults, according to an interim analysis that the drugmaker said was encouraging.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Rollout Calls for Supply-Chain Collaboration, Logistics Chief Says
summary: Kuehne + Nagel CEO Detlef Trefzger says rush will be manageable despite strains on transportation capacity. Capacity-strained shipping networks should be able to manage the rush to distribute Covid-19 vaccines if governments, logistics providers and pharmaceutical companies coordinate their efforts, the head of a top global logistics operator says.

title: Uber, Lyft Face a No-Sharing Economy
summary: Coronavirus drags on ride-hailing firms, as Americans move out of cities and car sales climb again. Ride-hailing companies were counting on Americans becoming less-enamored of that new-car smell. What they didn't expect was the renewed value of only inhaling your own germs.

title: Covid-19 Vaccine Makers See Egypt as Crucial Launchpad
summary: Egypt offers platform to deliver vaccine to hundreds of millions of people across Middle East and Africa. Egypt is emerging as a critical proving ground for global powers seeking to export a coronavirus vaccine to the developing world.

title: Nickel for Electric Vehicles Is a Dime a Dozen
summary: The metal is an increasingly important commodity for the likes of Tesla, but investors shouldn't bet on a shortage yet. Will the electric-vehicle industry run short of nickel? It is a possibility, but investors shouldn't bet on a cobalt-style rally soon.

title: Corporate Defaults Slow, Lifting Debt Market
summary: Moody's recorded just 11 defaults in August and September among U.S. borrowers; trend seems to be holding. Fewer major U.S. companies are defaulting on their debt than investors feared just months ago, a boost to corporate bond prices and an encouraging sign for the U.S. economy.

title: SEC Provides Fewer Warnings of Potential Civil Action
summary: General Electric and Under Armour are among companies that were warned, and received Wells notices. Fewer companies are receiving warnings of potential civil-enforcement actions from the Securities and Exchange Commission as businesses under investigation increasingly opt to defend themselves before receiving a "Wells notice."

title: Banks Navigate Hazy Regulations to Serve Cannabis Businesses
summary: Financial institutions and fintech companies have been relying on data and old-fashioned site visits to manage risks. Many financial institutions looking to offer banking services to the expanding number of legal cannabis growers and distributors in the U.S. are still limited by spotty regulations and expensive compliance efforts.

title: Pandemic Fatigue Is Real-And It's Spreading
summary: Collective exhaustion with coronavirus restrictions has emerged as a formidable adversary for governments. From the corridors of Washington to the cobblestones of Paris, the coronavirus is roaring back and authorities are ramping up restrictions again. This time around, however, everyone is tired.

title: Bayer to Buy Gene-Therapy Firm AskBio for Up to $4 Billion
summary: Deal would boost German company's drugs pipeline as coronavirus, Roundup lawsuits squeeze results. BERLIN- Bayer AG said Monday it would pay as much as $4 billion for U.S. biotech firm Asklepios BioPharmaceutical Inc. to strengthen the German company's drugmaking arm, as Bayer continues to reel from its acquisition of crops giant Monsanto.

title: Coca-Cola Backs Away From Bottling in Australia as Deal Bubbles to Sell Stake
summary: The beverage company has agreed in principle to sell its 31% stake in Coca-Cola Amatil to a European affiliate. SYDNEY- Coca-Cola Co. agreed in principle to sell its stake in its Australian bottler to one of its European affiliates, its latest move to reduce exposure to costly bottling operations and focus on the more lucrative concentrate-making business.

title: PG&E Cuts Power to Hundreds of Thousands
summary: California utility's largest pre-emptive blackout of the year is the latest effort to avoid sparking wildfires. PG&E Corp. said it was pre-emptively cutting power to about 361,000 customers in northern and central California in an effort to prevent wildfires, marking the largest such shut-off it has reported this year.

title: The Dodgers Are One Win Away From World Series Title
summary: Los Angeles bounced back to take Game 5 after a solid performance from ace Clayton Kershaw in a 4-2 victory. ARLINGTON, Texas-The concept of momentum hardly matters in baseball, the only sport where the most important person on the field-namely the starting pitcher-changes every day. The Los Angeles Dodgers demonstrated as much Sunday night.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Spirited Performances (Monday Crossword, October 26)
